titleStmt.title: Minutes of Historical Advisory Committee Meeting, August 1994
HAC Meeting Minutes, 1994

div.head: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION August 5, 1994

p.hi: Bureau of Public Affairs, Office of the Historian

list.item: David Langbart, Archivist, Records Appraisal and Disposition Division
Marvin Russell, Chief, General Archives Review Branch
Jeanne Schauble, Director, Records Declassification Division
Thomas Johnson, Deputy Director, Center for Cryptologic History

row.cell: Report by the Historian, William Z. Slany
Report by Archivist David A. Langbart
Report on the Johnson Library Telephone Transcripts
Committee Consideration of Foreign Government Information
Report on Appeal of Declassification Reviews of Foreign Relations Volumes
Report on Declassification Review and Opening at NARA of Department of state Records
Annex: Remarks to the Advisory Committee on Historical Diplomatic Documentation by David A. Langbart, NARA

div.p: Before the meeting began, a Department of state photographer took a picture of all the Committee members.

Chairman Kimball opened the meeting at 9:07 a.m. He announced that Deputy Assistant Secretary Bennett Freeman would not be attending the meeting. He expressed concern that the minutes for the meetings were so late in being distributed. Slany promised that the minutes for this meeting would be available in draft before the next meeting in November.
Kimball asked Slany for his report on the status of the Foreign Relations series.

head.hi: Report by The Historian, William Z. Slany

div.p: Slany noted that he wanted to discuss three issues that he had not included in his written report:

item.p: 1) relations with the CIA and access to and use of their documents;
2) status of research in the Nixon papers;

div.p: Regarding the CIA, he thanked the Committee for its intervention at a time when several volumes were blocked in the declassification process at the Agency. However, some problems remain. He asked for Committee involvement in gaining complete access to CIA records and access to documents 26 years old and less, especially as historians are compiling volumes for the Johnson and Nixon years.

Kimball mentioned that if the executive order moves to the 25-year mark, Foreign Relations will have a bigger problem. Perhaps the Committee could ask Frank Sieverts (Senate Foreign Relations Committee) to add a rider to a bill allowing HO historians access prior to the 30-year timeline. The 26-year line had been a placebo to the CIA, and if they won’t cooperate, then it should be amended in such a way as to afford the access needed by the Department’s historians.
Leffler asked Kimball to write a letter to CIA in the name of the Committee requesting access for HO historians prior to the 26-year line. Kimball agreed to write the letter.

Herring asked what citation HO was using for CIA records. LaFantasie replied that the compilers were only able to use “Director’s Files.” Keefer and Schwar noted that they know what files the documents come from but the information cannot be included in the volumes.
LaFantasie said that we know where the files are from but not where they might go.

Kimball pointed out that they had discussed this issue before, and maybe the Committee should go to the CIA to talk about this. Nelson said, and Kimball agreed, that they needed to talk to the people who could make the decisions. Herring noted that the CIA advisory committee had met and in its report mentioned the lack of citations in CIA publications. The Committee should put pressure on the CIA and try to force the issue.

Leffler suggested writing a letter enumerating the issues and inviting the Committee to the CIA to discuss them. Kimball agreed, noting that the letter would include access prior to 26 years and citations to CIA records. An off-the-record discussion followed.

Rosenberg wanted to add the point that the State declassification people need CIA assistance in declassifying records at the Suitland Records Center, as the CIA had promised. Kimball said he had talked to Chaddic about Chaddic’s May 19 letter to Jack Wright, head of the CIA’s office that handles FOIA requests, asking for CIA assistance. Then both he and Slany had called Wright.

Kimball reported that Wright had said the CIA was looking at this issue but was “deeply divided” on how to handle it: one group wanted each unit to review its own documents; the other group wanted a team
to review all documents. Parts of the Agency did not want to delegate declassification authority outside their specific areas. Wright said he was thinking of sending a team to Suitland within the next 2 weeks.
Kimball decided that if, by August 17, neither Slany nor Chaddic had an answer from Wright, Slany will call Wright to remind him of his promise.

Rosenberg said that the letter should contain a statement that the Committee encourages the use of assessment teams with members from all concerned agencies to assist with declassification. The Committee decided that the letter should go to CIA Executive Director Leo Hazlewood and that it was important to meet with decision makers within the agency. Kimball offered to send a draft to all the members.
Van Camp asked if access to 26-year old documents was an issue with other agencies. Slany answered that all agencies are affected by this 26-year minimum.

Herring asked if the HO historians have complete access to CIA records. Slany said that no one knows for sure. Rosenberg asked if the compilers are getting useful material from the CIA. Keefer said that they are getting more each time they go, that the CIA History Staff is also getting more, even though the directorates do not like giving up their records. The Agency seems to keep everything, and the lists of job numbers are not very helpful as a guide.
Rosenberg asked if they were overloading the historians with “everything.” No one knew for sure. She asked about the finding aids.
Keefer and Schwar said that HO historians have no access to the most useful finding aids that the CIA has on microfilm.
LaFantasie noted that HO needs to explain access to CIA records in the volumes’ prefaces. He had no desire to point a finger at the CIA History Staff or at the Agency. Slany agreed.
A discussion followed about language for the preface to inform the users that the provenance for CIA documents was incomplete and “inadequate for research purposes.”

Slany continued his report, commenting on the status of the Nixon project. HO intends to arrange during the fall and winter the terms under which HO historians can do preliminary work in 1995. An off-the-record discussion followed.

Slany had one last comment: the CIA clearance bottleneck has been overcome, but HO now has a problem filling historian vacancies. State is operating under a freeze that prevents outside hiring and PA already exceeds its assigned FTE (full-time equivalency) level. This complicates the difficulty in recruiting people with the necessary skills and knowledge. Assistant Secretary Donilon has asked Under Secretary for Management Moose for a waiver to lift the freeze and hire historians. The bottom line is that the schedule is being compromised because of inadequate staffing.
Kimball pointed out that this sentiment is repeated in the Committee’s annual report and asked if the Committee wanted to send a memorandum to Moose reiterating its concern.
Leffler and Nelson said the Committee should wait until Moose makes a decision on the Japan appeal before sending him a memorandum regarding hiring. All agreed.

Taylor inquired about final declassification of the Africa 1961-1963 volume. Herschler’s report indicates that four documents are pending CIA review. Herschler explained that these are National Intelligence Estimates and the CIA expects to clear the documents in the next 2 weeks.
Leffler wanted to hear reports at the next meeting on the 1964-1968 Cyprus volume and the 1961-1963 Angola volume. Kimball said that he and Herring would report on these volumes in the afternoon.
This completed Slany’s report.

head.hi: Report by Archivist David A. Langbart

div.p: Kimball called on David Langbart to present his report on records disposition. (His written report is attached.)
Langbart said he would discuss three issues:

item.p: 1) disposition of records regarding Foreign Relations declassification;
2) disposition of Bureau of African Affairs post-war lot files; and
3) disposition of World War II naval records.

div.p: He informed the Committee that no agency can destroy records without permission of the Archivist of the United States and the final decision to keep or destroy records rests with NARA. Donating records must also be approved by NARA.

Regarding the Foreign Relations declassification records, NARA determined to keep HO files instead of those held by HDR. (HO files also included Committee records.) HDR files have been recommended for destruction.

Regarding the AF lot files, he noted that this was the first time the lot files of a whole bureau had been scheduled all together. All have been approved for accession except the files of two regional offices. Those records will be destroyed.

The World War II naval cryptologic files are important because they document the impact of radio intelligence and crypto on naval operations. The pre-1946 files -- 2,000 cubic feet plus 15,000 feet of microfilm -- will be transferred as Naval records. The post-1946 records will be retained at the Department of the Navy. There will be minimal archival processing. NSA, which has authority over crypto files, has refused to bulk declassify. Access will depend on FOIA requests.

Kimball had some comments. He questioned the NARA decision not to accession HDR files. Herschler said that the HO files were not complete for volumes from the creation of CDC/HDR in
1981 until the transfer of the coordination function from HDR to HO in mid-1993. Langbart pointed out that the essential documentation is duplicated.
Kimball asked if the Committee wanted to get involved. Langbart commented that these were not high policy matters. Kimball therefore recommended that HO and NARA resolve this between them.

Slany gave the Committee some background on the AF lot files: HO was worried that these records would be destroyed and recommended they be transferred to Howard University if it would accept them. NARA then reconsidered its initial decision to destroy them. Langbart noted that NARA was now waiting for State’s concurrence in the revised disposition schedule. Bates (IS/OIS/RA/RD) said she was waiting for HO to indicate how long the historians needed or wanted to keep the files before she returned the schedule to NARA. The issue was when to destroy the records, not if they will be destroyed. Slany again mentioned sending the records to Howard.

Lawler, who had served as a country desk officer, was opposed to destruction of lot files. Bates explained that her office had developed screening guidelines that would ensure that unique documents in the lot files would be sent to OIS to be included in the central files.
Kimball asked about the possibility that some other institution would be willing to keep the records.
Rossman pointed out that donating classified records is very expensive: they must first be declassified and then managed according to government regulations.

Taylor asked if Howard could offer a subvention to NARA to finance. Langbart replied that a subvention would have to cover all costs. And the issue of donation cannot be discussed until the records have been scheduled for disposal.

Kimball was incredulous that the problem had to be solved before it happened; he asked if the Committee could discuss the issue hypothetically. Langbart said that even if the Department wants to address this issue, nothing can be done until the schedules are signed.

Rossman said that Department records managers believed that the records should be retained, but expert appraisers from NARA had reappraised the records and decided they should be destroyed. It’s hard to discuss the issue without looking at the records, and he trusted the decision of these expert appraisers. Bates said that she was willing to hold the records as long as HO needed them.
Langbart clarified that the records dated only from 1990; everything previous had been screened and destroyed.

Pryor commented that country officers’ files differ throughout the Department of State. Some contain unique documentation including copies of documents with handwritten notes. Each file must be appraised on its own merits.
Kimball recommended additional study, and he asked Van Camp to form a subcommittee with Leffler and Taylor to study the issue and come back to the Committee with recommendations.
Kimball reserved discussion of Langbart’s third issue until after the break.
The Committee adjourned for a break at 10:39 a.m.

After the break, Kimball indicated that the issue up for discussion was the declassification review of records of Navy cryptographers, dating from the 1920s to 1945, which had recently been transferred to NARA.

Kimball introduced Thomas Johnson from NSA. Johnson indicated that the records contained no cryptographic sensitivity, but that there was some concern in NSA that some post-1945 records might be mixed in with the pre-1945 records transferred to NARA. Thus some screening might be necessary, although no decision had yet been made on dealing with this problem.

Johnson further stated that his office had proposed that the records undergo bulk declassification, offering his personal opinion that bulk declassification would be the only way to go. The issue was still in the discussion stage. Current plans called for initial declassification of German U-Boat records, followed by Japanese intercepts from the 1920s
to 1945. Other increments would follow, but the schedule had not been worked out beyond these two record segments.
Kimball asked if archivists from NARA could thumb through the documents to determine if some were post 1945. Kimball also wondered why the Japanese records were not the first priority.

Leffler proposed that the Committee write NSA a friendly letter proposing that the declassification process be completed by a specified date, a 50-year line. He hoped that NSA’s bulk declassification then could be used as a precedent and would encourage others to release 50-year old documents.

Langbart stated that NARA personnel had done the segregation of the material transferred to NARA and that the paper records consisted exclusively of material dated prior to the end of World War II. However, the microfilm portion of the collection included material that post-dated 1945.It had made sense to take all the microfilm irrespective of date. Post-1945 material will have to be accessed through FOIA. Langbart indicated that there was a good roll list for the microfilm but that it was codeword-level classified, and he hoped it could be declassified.
Johnson said he could not respond since he had not looked at the list. The NSA had not yet finally decided on bulk declassification, but Johnson thought it was probably the only solution.

Kimball stated that liaison was needed between NSA and NARA to reassure NSA about post-1945 material in the pre-1945 records. He asked Slany to keep the Committee informed of developments concerning the material.

Langbart noted that NSA was seeking to schedule other pre-1945 material and transfer the original records to NARA. Kimball mentioned the “Yardley material” and indicated that he had heard that the State Department was holding it up.

Kimball then introduced another issue involving NSA: a memorandum of understanding between HO and NSA on access to NSA records by HO historians. Johnson thought that existing
arrangements might be adequate. He stated that he would explore the status of that problem in NSA. Kimball indicated that he wanted to be informed of progress on this issue.

Hamilton responded to a query by Chairman Kimball during the break. HDR had received a request from NSA to consider release of a bloc of World War II period files. HDR had responded by suggesting that NSC wait until issuance of the expected new Executive Order governing material prior to 1950 as that might make review unnecessary.
Regarding new Executive orders, Kimball stated he had no new information beyond what Freeman had said at lunch the day before. He expected further discussion of the matter at lunch today.

head.hi: Report on the Johnson Library Telephone Transcripts

div.p: Nelson reported that the tapes made for fascinating listening and there is no substitute for hearing them. A transcript does not do a conversation justice. The tapes had surprisingly good audio quality. The subcommittee definitely agreed that they should be used in Foreign Relations volumes. The subcommittee suggested that the Committee write to Harry Middleton giving him a broad statement of support and stating that it appreciated the difficulties faced by the Library. The letter should state that the tapes will greatly amplify the documents printed in Foreign Relations volumes. The problem for HO historians was that the deadlines for the volumes will occur before all the relevant tapes are reviewed.

Van Camp expounded on the problems: duplication; and the time needed to review the conversations under the donor’s deed of gift. The Johnson Library would like to review the tapes chronologically; HO wants them reviewed topically to fit its publishing schedule. The solution suggested by HO was to identify priority tapes within discernible time frames and ask the Library to review on that basis. Van Camp agreed that the tapes added an important new dimension, especially in style and interaction of personalities. Johnson was a verbal person, not one given to writing.
Nelson noted that although the tapes are a definite plus, they add another problem to meeting deadlines.

Kimball stated that Harry Middleton should be encouraged to accept HO’s priority list. Van Camp suggested that it be a supportive letter. Herring noted that Middleton is taking a risk by opening these tapes before the 50-year restriction.

Humphrey agreed that a letter was a good idea. He noted there were some 275 transcripts of conversations with Rusk, McNamara, and McGeorge Bundy already in HO’s possession. But there are many more conversations by these men for which there are no transcripts, and there are other important people Johnson talked to.

Kimball asked if HO had sole access. Humphrey answered that it did. Davis stated that he supported the subcommittee views as presented by Nelson and Van Camp and agreed there was no substitute for listening to the tapes.
Slany asked that the Committee remind NARA not to use the Department of State funded position, the subvention, to fortify position strength in the face of the pressures to reduce personnel.
Humphrey stated that the position as funded by the Department of State was a 2-year temporary position without job security and it might be difficult to convince a NARA employee to accept it.
Kimball asked why a 2-year temporary job. Why not a transfer? Humphrey responded that NARA’s problem would be saving the job-slot for 2 years if it was not temporary.
Kimball was dubious about telling NARA and Trudy Peterson how to to do their job. Nelson wondered if NARA could not be convinced to add another position to the task.
Slany suggested that the Committee stress its commitment to the project. Kimball suggested that it would be best to do this informally. Nelson agreed to pass it to Trudy Peterson on that basis.

head.hi: Committee Consideration of Foreign Government Information

div.p: Herschler then commented on the issue of foreign government information, indicating that there had been some success in dealing with FGI problems in the months since his written report had been prepared. Nelson noted that Herschler’s report contained nothing new on the issue of FGI. Kimball asked whether there had been any progress in getting the British to agree to release documents at the 30-year line following a review prior to the 30-year mark. It was indicated that no such progress had been made.

Pryor discussed a meeting with British representative Richard Bone, who stated that he saw no possibility of releasing British documents short of the 30-year mark even if the new U.S. Executive order established a 25-year time line.

Schwar questioned HO’s agreement with the British on identifying British documents denied because they are less than 30 years old in Foreign Relations volumes. The agreement specified that such documents should be identified only by year and place of origin and by the term “Intergovernmental Communication.”

Several members of the Committee expressed opposition to this arrangement. It was noted that U.S. law called for fuller identification of denied documents and that the Committee had been urging the CIA to follow proper procedure. Kimball stated that this was not a negotiable issue and that HO should not abide by the agreement with the British.

Slany agreed that if the Committee thought the arrangement for citing documents less than 30 years old that was reached with the British was inadequate, then HO will reopen the issue. He noted that the Committee’s reach was now crossing the Atlantic. Slany stressed that HO will have to present the British with the argument that the Advisory Committee insists upon renegotiation.
The Committee adjourned for lunch at noon.
The Committee reconvened at 1:15 p.m. The members approved the Annual Report, and Kimball asked Slany to circulate it to the professional associations, members of Congress, etc.

head.hi: Report on Appeal of Declassification Reviews of Foreign Relations Volumes

div.p: The Committee then turned to the report by the subcommittee, consisting of Rosenberg, Leffler, Taylor, and Kimball, which reviewed the documents on Japan for Foreign Relations, 1961-1963 (including some 1958-1960 documents). It was pointed out that the 60-day clock had not yet started for the appeal on the British Guyana compilation but was over for the Japan compilation. Taylor asked if the Committee should submit an addendum to the appeal package as suggested by Bennett Freeman.

Rosenberg pointed out that the Committee had essentially three choices: let the documents go without action; write a letter to Moose with a fuller rationale and ask Slany to attach it to the appeal package; or follow Quainton’s suggestion of attaching a statement on this subject to the new Executive order to the effect that some embarrassing things might be released as a result. Attaching the Foreign Relations series to the Executive order might be an ingenious solution. She thought that a possible course of action might be a follow-up letter to Moose that would summarize the Committee’s arguments without reference to the Executive order.

Nelson agreed with Rosenberg that a letter should be sent, but it should not be tied to the Executive order. Kimball wondered whether a letter to Moose was necessary. Moose showed the Committee at lunch that he understands all the issues, and he listened carefully. Herring pointed out that Moose’s last words were, “I understand the seriousness of your position.”

Kimball suggested that Slany find out if anything else was required. Rosenberg asked Slany for his opinion, and Slany responded that he thought a decision would be made by next week. He also thought there was little else that the Committee could do at this time.

Nelson reiterated that the Committee had had a good lunch with Moose, and Kimball concluded that the Committee should do nothing. Bennett Freeman could find out what, if anything, needed to be done. Rosenberg recalled that Moose had said that release of the documents might cause a flap in Japan and she wondered if he realized that non-release might cause a big flap here.

Van Camp asked whether the Committee had to take any action before next week. Kimball said that he would be on vacation next week so if the Committee wanted to write a letter to Moose, someone else should draft it. Leffler agreed to write the letter, if necessary. Davis said that if there was not much to lose by writing a letter, then the Committee should do it. Kimball thought there was something to lose because he believed Moose was the type of person who could be annoyed by excessive amounts of paper. Leffler added that he thought the Committee was going to lose on this issue, and it would be much better to press on the issue of Guyana, a country of less importance to current U.S. foreign policy.

Kimball then mentioned the documents for the Japan volume sanitized by HO. The concept was left in, but the real issue is that this activity was part of U.S. policy. He asked what if Moose allowed this issue to sit. The 60 days are up.

When Leffler asked whether Guyana will be up for decision, Kimball answered affirmatively. Leffler then said that if the Committee waited until the next meeting on both the Japan and Guyana issues, it might find two bad decisions without an opportunity to have any input beforehand. He agreed to monitor the situation with Slany.

Nelson reminded the Committee members that they had already told Moose that the Japan compilation probably would not be printed. Kimball added that in May the Committee recommended that the Northeast Asia volume be published without the Japan compilation, but “Japan” would appear on the spine of the volume and in the Table of Contents. The withholding of the Guyana compilation, however, would prevent the publication of the entire volume on the American Republics. Nelson said it
was too bad the Committee did not tell Moose about its May decisions on the Japan compilation, but Leffler and Herring believed that the Committee members had gotten across the essential points to Moose.

The Committee then turned to the compilations on Cyprus and Greece (1964-1968) and on Angola (1961-1963). Herring called the reviews in both cases “outrageous” and “ridiculous.” In the case of Angola, only a few documents were involved. No rationale had been given for the denials. Kimball said that the decision had been made by the Angola and Portugal desks, although HDR had recommended clearance of all the documents with perhaps one exception.

Howland interjected that the desk officer argued that the release of the documents on this issue, which was inherited from the Eisenhower administration, would harm current U.S. relations with Portugal. Kimball pointed out that Kissinger had acknowledged U.S. assistance to Angolan liberation groups in congressional hearings in the mid-1970s. LaFantasie and Herschler both commented that HO could not get a substantive answer on the reasons for the denials.

On Greece and Cyprus, Kimball said that the compiler had noted that the office director had been uncooperative, even “rude” to the compiler when he requested the reasons for the denials. The office director, claiming the issue had already been decided, refused to meet with HO. There was an “attitude problem” here. The volume was being typeset now, but documents could be added later. Kimball thought no action was required now, but the attitude problem should be addressed.

Kimball told the Committee members that they could read the compiler’s memorandum on the subject. Kimball added that Slany has promised to get Freeman to convene a working group that might promote more cooperation.
Miller noted that the appeal on his volume (Greece, Turkey, Cyprus) would be directed to the Director of the Office of Southern European Affairs (Adair), rather than a desk officer.

On Tibet, Kimball remarked that HO had gone back to the CIA declassification staff with documents for decision, but the directorates have been obdurate and have not made a decision. The 60-day clock has been “broken,” and the Committee needs an appropriate answer by its next meeting.

head.hi: Report on Declassification Review and Opening at NARA of Department of State Records

div.p: The Committee took up the proposed Executive order on the declassification of World War II documents. Russell (NARA) noted that there was disagreement about the scope of the new Executive order. Chaddic said that HDR was in the process of re-reviewing approximately 250,000 pages of pre-1950 documents; some were pre-1945. Most of the previously withheld documents were now releasable. Once the new Executive order was issued, review of withheld records would be expedited according to the E.O.’s new criteria.

Kimball then urged the automatic release of all pre-1945 State documents. Chaddic said that if he could have his way, all these documents would be available immediately. Kimball said that all he wanted was to make HDR’s job easier by not having it review documents unnecessarily, especially because many of the documents were dated before 1945.

Nelson asked what reasons existed beyond “national security” that would prevent the opening of the pre-1945 documents, and Chaddic responded that the documents contain FBI and intelligence materials. Rosenberg said she had seen some of the boxes and documents had been withheld by both CIA and by State. Chaddic replied that under the new Executive order a smaller percentage would be held back, but until the new order State would continue to withhold documents.

Kimball asked how national security could possibly be affected by pre-1945 documents. He said that he was concerned with the standards HDR was using to guide its declassification decisions; he wondered whether HDR might be too quick not to declassify documents. Chaddic replied that foreign government
information was usually the reason, although he admitted that some items had been inappropriately withheld.

Rosenberg observed that a further problem at NARA was the requirement that HDR personnel complete cover sheets for code-word documents. Chaddic said that there were more code-word documents than expected, and he was working to revise that procedure.

The Committee turned to Chaddic’s letter to Wright (CIA) and the follow-up telephone calls. Kimball repeated that the CIA was divided on declassification. Wright had suggested that he might send a team drawn from the various CIA directorates to NARA in 2 weeks to assist in the declassification of CIA documents. Slany was asked to monitor Wright’s replies.

Leffler then said that during his visit to Suitland he reviewed the “guidelines” for reviewers. He pointed to the example of India (through 1963). He was “appalled” at the restrictive language, which called for the withholding of any information relating to counteracting Soviet actions in India as well as any derogatory language about the motives or objectives of Indian Government policy. He suggested that at each upcoming meeting a subcommittee look at the guidelines for two or three countries and see if they were appropriate for the post-Cold War world.

Chaddic emphasized that the guidelines were written for NARA reviewers, not for HDR, and specified areas where documents should be referred to the State Department for decision. Now there is one-step declassification review by HDR. There are about 115 guidelines, mostly geographic, and a few on Latin America and Africa cover three or four countries. There were also guidelines on about six general subjects, such as petroleum, Law of the Sea, and international organizations. He had a complete set of the guidelines in his office.

When Leffler asked if the guidelines could be changed, Chaddic said he would consider suggestions. Nelson said it was difficult to evaluate guidelines and how they were interpreted in practice. Leffler said they were in the reviewers’ heads now when they made decisions denying material.

Nelson then offered a summary of her subcommittee’s visit to HDR. She described the process in which the withdrawn documents were separated from the cleared ones. The “open” boxes contained withdrawal sheets for those items withdrawn. Then HDR would write guidelines for other agency “equity,” which NARA would apply. NARA would take over these documents this September, but there was a potential problem because it was not clear whether NARA would simply store them or formally take custody of them.

Nelson reported that NARA seemed pleased with the declassification review by the State Department. The subcommittee looked at withdrawn documents, but there was not enough time to look at many. Most documents were withdrawn because of foreign government information. In at least one case she agreed that the document should be withdrawn, but other cases were not so clear-cut.

Overall this system was much quicker and more competent, she thought, and HDR would likely complete the review by September. This was later clarified; HDR hopes to begin reviewing the political files in September. The State Department offices housing the documents were, however, very crowded; no center or work area had been established. There will still be guidelines, but Nelson endorsed Leffler’s suggestion that a subcommittee review the guidelines at future Committee meetings.
Kimball wondered whether it might be time to issue an ultimatum to other agencies: unless we hear otherwise, we will release your documents. He doubted that many would respond.

Van Camp disagreed with Nelson’s comment that the subcommittee did not have enough time to review documents. She noted NARA’s concerns and felt that NARA and State should not blame each other. When there was talk of the 1964-66 documents being open, did that mean only after the documents were transferred to Archives II?

Michael Kurtz affirmed that all the RG 59 records, including the 1960-63 Central File documents reviewed by HDR, would be sent to Archives II in September. This had been
worked out with Chaddic, Machak, and Rossman. “Open” meant for public access. Their problem was the hiring freeze at NARA (45-50 vacancies). State reviewers had reviewed the Central, post, and lot files, so that deadlines could be met. So, Kimball asked, are we going to meet the schedule? (Heads nodded.)

Nelson mentioned that Chaddic agreed that there would still be guidelines. Barr noted that the talk about the guidelines was not entirely accurate, as HDR reviewers often used them as a “framework” for their review. The HDR reviewers were not experts on every part of the world, but the guidelines allowed them to make decisions on everything. Kimball said there would be a NARA subcommittee during the next meeting of the Committee, and he might want to be on it. He agreed when Rosenberg pointed out that the Committee needed to select the countries for which it wanted to review the guidelines.

Kimball then asked about the “Yardley” material. Chaddic noted that these were the “Magic” records. HDR had received a request from NSA for bulk declassification of the 1942-1945 records. INR was opposed to bulk declassification, and HDR asked NSA to put these documents on hold until the new Executive order on World War II records was issued. The NSA position was that these Magic records contained nothing on sources and methods, but Hamilton pointed out that INR argued that they include diplomatic intercepts. He did not agree with the NSA representative (Johnson) in the morning session that these records were limited to the 1930s.
Kurtz pointed out that the proposed new Executive order applied only to those documents already accessioned by NARA. Chaddic did not realize this.

Kimball stated that he was at loss about how to handle this issue. He was appalled at the notion that any agency thinks that records that old are still sensitive. INR should explain its position, which seems “irrational.” The Committee might send a letter to the agencies asking for their explanations.

Chaddic said the State Department was not ready to go to bulk declassification, but he was willing to go back to INR and
NSA and try to work it out. He personally did not see anything that needed to be withheld. Rosenberg thought the Committee should ask HDR for a verbal report next time on this issue. Kimball agreed. Nelson and Kimball added that NARA should be included.
This session ended at 3:10 p.m.
Joe Chaddic left the room to a round of applause; it was his final official appearance before the Committee.
Kimball asked if the staff would like to make any comments.

Keefer commented that it is the “same old story,” citing the recurring problems with the LBJ tapes and files transferred to Archives II. These problems, and the consequent delays in compiling, are making it difficult to meet the schedule.

Kimball replied that, although the compilers must by law adhere to the schedule, the Advisory Committee had resolved that the quality of the Foreign Relations series must not be compromised in the process. If specific problems arise, the Committee will deal with them on a case-by-case basis.
Nelson said that the Committee would need to step in if any problems should arise with Archives II, e.g., transfer of records, copying, etc. Kimball agreed.
Kimball thanked Keefer for raising the issue {schedule vs. quality) again. He suggested that Slany or LaFantasie should let the Committee know if the compilers required any further assistance.

Miller explained that the Historian’s Office was relying on the 1991 Foreign Relations statute to secure access to other agency records. A contact of his at CIA, however, had informed him that the Agency had other statutes to consider -- statutes that were in conflict with the Foreign Relations law. Miller said it was difficult for the CIA to appreciate the HO point of view, especially since the unauthorized disclosure of information could lead to disciplinary action by the Agency against its employees, i.e., termination.

Kimball explained that Frank Sieverts (Senate Foreign Relations Committee) had tried to resolve any discrepancies between the relevant statutes, but had been forced to finesse the issue in order to ensure passage of the Foreign Relations legislation.

Nelson cited the possibility of conflict of the Foreign Relations statute with the National Security Act of 1947. Kimball agreed with Nelson’s assessment that any further legislation might have to exclude the CIA from participation.
Kimball adjourned the meeting at 3:20 p.m. and the Committee went into executive session.

head.hi: REMARKS TO THE ADVISORY COMITTEE ON HISTORICAL DIPLOMATIC DOCUMENTATION

div.p: (DAVID A. LANGBART, NARA)

I have been asked to speak to you about three things, two concerning recent ongoing developments regarding records of the Department of State and one relating to records of interest to this committee: one, Foreign Relations clearance files maintained by the Historical Documents Review Division; two, selected records of the Bureau of African Affairs; and, three, world war II era Navy crypto records.

Before discussing these three topics, I think it might be l useful to say a few words about the process of scheduling records. By law, agencies are required to schedule their records and no Federal records may be destroyed without the approval of the Archivist of the United States. For the most part, the process begins when an agency submits a schedule to the National Archives and Records Administration. On a schedule, an agency identifies series of records and proposes a disposition (for example destruction after a period of time or future transfer to the National Archives). It is the responsibility of the NARA staff to review the records and, in the context of all relevant records, make a final decision on whether they are only of temporary value or warrant permanent retention in the National Archives. We may sustain an agency’s recommendation or we may decide that the records warrant a different disposition, but the final decision rests with NARA. Notices are published in the
Federal Register of all schedules calling for the destruction of records or a reduction in retention period. Persons interested in a particular schedule may request a copy and then provide us with comments.

One possible means of disposing of records that NARA determines to be temporary is donation to an appropriate person, organization, institution, corporation or government that has requested them. No records may be donated without prior written approval from NARA. Among the limiting factors involved, donations must be done at no cost to the government and the records may contain no information the disclosure of which is prohibited by law or is contrary to the public interest.

One pending schedule covers the Foreign Relatione of the United States Record File created and maintained by HDR. In addition to the schedule from HDR, we also received a schedule covering the records of the Historical Office. That schedule, also still pending, includes an item for HO’s Foreign Relations Clearance File. After reviewing records covered by these two schedules, we chose to focus our attention on the HO files because that office has ultimate responsibility for the Foreign Relations series. Furthermore, its clearance files contain essentially the same information as the HDR review files and they cover all volumes since the World War II compilations. Despite the fact that these are essentially routine publication clearance files, in recognition of the importance of the series,
controversies surrounding compilation and declassification, and in the hope that somebody might some day write a history of the publication, NASA determined that the HO publication clearance files warrant eventual transfer to the National Archives and that is how the schedule sent for signing reads. Since the material in the HDR files is essentially duplicated in HO files we determined that it is not necessary to preserve both series and the HDR records are scheduled for eventual destruction, you may be interested to know that the HO schedule also provides coverage for the records of this advisory committee.

The set of six schedules covering records of the Bureau of African Affairs, submitted by the Department on December 18, 1992, represent the first time all records of a geographic bureau have been scheduled. In the past, we have received schedules covering only isolated series maintained by any geographic bureau. Appraising all of the records of a bureau at one time provided valuable context for us in making our decisions. The six schedules cover:

item.p: 1. the Assistant Secretary and other Front Office records
5. the Office of the Executive Director

div.p: All but the two schedules covering the Office of Regional Affairs and the geographic offices have been approved by the Acting Archivist.

During review of the records, we determined that the annual Program Files of the Office of Regional Affairs and the geographic offices do not merit transfer to the National Archives. It is important to note that the proposed schedules do not make all records of those offices disposable. Both schedules call for transfer to the National Archives of Special Collections of files. Those records generally cover on-going issues and special problems for which an annual cut off of files would not be appropriate. The schedule for the geographic offices also designates as permanent records of bureau-level task forces and working groups, briefing books, and certain Fair Labor Standards files unique to the Office of South African Affairs. Significant documentation on African affairs will be found in the Automated Data System (ADS), the files of the Department’s principal officers (the Secretary of State, the Deputy Secretary, and the Under Secretaries), and the files of Foreign Service Posts. Other permanent records will also include documentation on African matters. The files we have appraised as disposable consist overwhelmingly of copies of telegrams, memorandums, and other documents that will be found among the permanent records of the Department of State. The schedules will genrally cover the period from 1990 to the present.

In reaching a final decision, we took some extraordinary steps because of the precedent setting nature of the work in this geographic bureau. After the initial appraisal and review, the Records Appraisal and Disposition Division held extensive internal discussions on this matter. In addition, we met with our colleagues in the Textual Projects Division and the Textual Reference Division to review and discuss the appraisal. That discussion upheld the conclusions of the initial appraisal. In order to ensure the best possible appraisal, however, we decided that a visit to the Department was warranted in order to conduct a further review of the records and to discuss the appraisal. The results of that review once again upheld the initial appraisal. The files reviewed by NARA staff consisted overwhelmingly of copies of telegrams. The files also include lesser amounts of other types of documents such as memorandums and correspondence. They contained only a handful of unique documents, certainly no more than one or two percent of the total volume, and those few items supplement in very modest fashion the permanent Department files that document decision making and policy formulation. We then prepared a report on our findings for the Acting Archivist who indicated approval. We are now waiting for the Department to revise the schedules as requested before they are sent for final approval. The situation in the Bureau of African Affairs is not unique. We have just concluded a review of the analogous files of the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs and reached the same conclusion about the annual program files of the geographic offices in that bureau.

The Navy intelligence records in question relate to World War II-era communications security and communications intelligence as well as Navy operational records supported by those programs. The records consist of a number of series, the most important of which are:

item.p: 4. Translations of Intercepted Enemy Radio Traffic and Miscellaneous World War II Documentation

div.p: In March 1993, at the request of the Naval Security Group Command, a successor to OP-20-G, two appraisal archivists visited the remote Navy storage facility and carried out an appraisal and review of the records. The pre-1946 records deal mostly with Navy radio intelligence and cryptography activities from the late 1930s through the end of World War II. They document the impact of radio intelligence and cryptographic work on Navy operations in all theaters of operations. Our conclusion was that these records are vital to analysis and understanding of Navy operations during World War II that they should retain their identity as Navy records and be transferred to the National Archives. Our recommendation received support from many elements within the Navy and legal transfer of the records took place in September 1993. Actual physical delivery of the records came in May of this year.

The records recently transferred to the National Archives
include approximately two thousand cubic feet of material including fifteen thousand three hundred and forty two rolls of microfilm. For the most part, the records transferred to the National Archives date to about 1946. Perhaps the most comprehensive records will be found on the microfilm. These include Japanese raw intercepts, station files, subject files from various OP-20 offices, German U-boat files, intercepted German clandestine traffic, analyses of intercepted German traffic, intercepted diplomatic traffic, ULTRA summaries, work sheets, captured documents, Navy message traffic, and other intelligence-related material. The Navy retains in its possession records from about 1946 to the present, included in the records retained by the Navy are files relating to both the U.S.S. Liberty and the U.S.S. pueblo.

The records we received in May of this year are in SCI storage at Archives 2. At this point, there has been minimal archival processing. We basically know where things are Declassification is dependent upon the National Security Agency which asserts authority over final declassification of all crypto records throughout the government. My understanding is that NSA is still trying to figure how to deal with these records. They are reluctant to commit to undertaking a systematic review of the files, particularly the microfilm. There is some discussion about a bulk declassification of the Japanese Orange Translations, but no final decision has been made. Therefore, access will be dependent upon FOIA requests unless something
happens to cause NSA to change its mind or policies. One thing I am happy to report is that NSA has scheduled for transfer the so-called Red Machine intercepts of Japanese diplomatic messages. The approximately 3300 translations cover the period from mid-1934 to the end of 1938.
